meta.title: OpenBuild – Build in Public Platform
meta.description:
Traditional portfolios show the finished product; OpenBuild shows the evolution.
By tracking daily build logs, technical decisions, and challenges, developers create a public paper trail of their learning and growth. OpenBuild then applies AI to convert this unstructured journey into structured, platform-ready narratives suitable for modern professional and social platforms.

logs.title: Project Initialization & Direction Setting
logs.content:
Started working on **OpenBuild**, a build-in-public platform for developers.

The first step was defining the direction of the project, so I focused on writing a clear README before writing any code. This helped me clarify the problem I’m solving and the long-term vision of the platform.

I initialized the GitHub repository and made the first commit with the initial project structure and documentation.

**Key decision:** Treat this project as a product, not just a demo — documentation and clarity come first.

logs.title: Building the core OpenBuild web interface
logs.content:
After defining the direction and vision for OpenBuild, the next step was to turn
that idea into something real.

I built the core web interface that powers the platform:
- A home feed to discover project updates from the community
- Dedicated project pages with a timeline-style journey log
- Pagination to handle growing build logs
- A sticky dashboard for quick navigation between projects

The focus wasn’t just visual design.
The UI is intentionally structured to encourage consistent, readable updates
that can later be processed as structured data for analytics and AI features.

This phase marked the transition of OpenBuild from a concept into a usable
build-in-public platform.

logs.title: Designing build-in-public posts as structured data
logs.content:
While working on OpenBuild, I realized that most build-in-public content is
great for humans but unstructured and inefficient for data and AI systems.

Instead of treating posts as plain text, I designed OpenBuild updates as
structured data points.

Each post captures:
- Project context
- Post type (start, progress, blocker, release)
- Timestamps
- Markdown structure
- Media attachments

This approach makes posts useful beyond just reading:
they become analyzable, searchable, and AI-ready.

The goal is simple — every post should work twice:
once for the community, and once as clean data for future AI features.

logs.title: Designing project journey logs for long-term consistency
logs.content:
As OpenBuild started collecting more updates, the next challenge was consistency
over time.

I designed project updates as a journey log rather than isolated posts.
Each project follows a timeline-based structure where progress, blockers,
and milestones are captured in sequence.

This approach helps in two ways:
- Developers can clearly see how a project evolved over time
- The data naturally forms a time-series that can later be analyzed or summarized

By treating each project as a continuous journey, OpenBuild encourages
accountability, reflection, and meaningful progress — not just final outcomes.
Early project updates were backfilled after the core platform stabilized,
so ordering is based on sequence rather than creation time.

logs.title: Structured updates: introducing post types in OpenBuild
logs.content:
As OpenBuild started growing beyond simple text updates, I realized that not all progress logs are the same.

Some posts introduce features, some fix bugs, others capture learnings — and treating everything as plain text would limit both clarity and future automation.

In this update, I introduced **Post Types** and updated the UI to support them.

**What changed:**
- Added a `post_type` field to posts (INIT, FEATURE, FIX, REFACTOR, DEPLOY, REFLECTION, UPDATE)
- Updated the post creation form with a clean dropdown
- Added helper descriptions in the UI for clarity and consistency
- Ensured structured data for future AI processing

This might look like a small UI change, but it’s a foundational step:
clean labels → better data → meaningful automation later.

Designing the data intentionally now makes it much easier to build AI features on top of it in the future.

Building slowly, but building right.

logs.title: Structured Progress: Introducing Post Types in OpenBuild
logs.content:
As OpenBuild started evolving, I realized that not all progress updates are the same.

Some posts are about adding features, some are reflections, others mark milestones.
Treating everything as a generic “update” would limit clarity — both for users and
for future automation.

So I introduced **Post Types** into OpenBuild.

Each project update can now be categorized as:
- **Init** — Starting a project or initial setup
- **Feature** — New functionality added
- **Fix** — Bugs or issues resolved
- **Decision** — Design or architecture choices
- **Milestone** — Major progress, releases, or deploys
- **Learning** — Reflections, lessons, and insights
- **Update** — General progress or small changes

This improves:
- Readability for people following a project
- Filtering and understanding progress over time
- Data quality for future AI features (summaries, scripts, insights)

This change required small but meaningful updates across:
- Database structure
- Post creation forms
- UI clarity and intent

A small feature on the surface — but an important foundation decision.

Building OpenBuild as a **product first**, AI later.
